channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: The Future is Now! Perl Role in Malaysia
item.description: If you’re a Perl programmer with a passion for finance, this role may be the one for you. Our client is a financial company whose stunning growth over the last twenty years shows that they belong in the city of the future. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Grow Your Karma with a Job that Does Good! Perl role in Australia
item.description: Not all jobs are created equal. Sure, most pay the bills, but some do more. They impart a sense of purpose; when you log out at day’s end, it’s with the satisfaction that you are part of something bigger, something more important than yourself. You’ve left the world a little better than you found it, and isn’t that what life is really about?

item.title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Perl in Vienna
item.description: Our client takes the legwork out of the hunt for the best bargain, offering one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re looking for a heroic Perl programmer to develop and deliver quality content and all the info users need to find their gadgets for the right price.

item.title: That’s a Big Sandbox! Perl role in London
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Cooking Up Something Good. Perl role in London
item.description: With a knack for tailoring content to a variety of site aesthetics, our client sets a banquet of advertising delights for over 349 million consumers around the world. If your mouth is watering at the thought of joining this dynamic team and you’re a senior Perl programmer with a solid understanding of Go programming languages, they just might set a place for you at the table.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud 2021
item.description: Online 9-11 June 2021.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will take place online between March 24-26 2021. A private ticket will be cheaper (EUR 30). People who register in time and pay the participation fee will get exclusive extras.

item.description: March 11th, 2021 06:00 PM Central Time (US and Canada)

item.description: Wednesday, March 10, 2021

item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Code Maven courses
item.description: Perl and other courses by Gabor Szabo

item.title: Which versions of Perl are you using?
item.description: A poll.

item.title: CPAN Testers or CI system?
item.description: CPAN Testers is a valuable service, but setting up a CI system will help you get earlier feedback and can do certain things that CPAN Testers don't provide.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 102
item.description: Luis shared multiple approaches dealing with task 1 and shared how each performed.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 102
item.description: I love the honesty as Simon confessed his solution is not the most optimal solution. Please check out the whole story.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 102: Rare Hash
item.description: Roger shared the performance of his solutions in Perl, Python and Ruby. Some interesting stats.

item.title: Perl weekly challenge 102
item.description: Most of all, I fell in love with the solution to task 2. Very clever solution. Well done.

item.title: PWC102 - Hash-counting String
item.description: Flavio threw out a challenge to readers of his blog. Find out more about it.

item.title: PWC102 - Rare Numbers
item.description: For me, the section "The questions" is more important than "The solution". He explained in great detail.

item.title: Rare Numbers and Hash: Perl Challenge #102
item.description: Dave shared his fight with the weekly task. You learn a lot by just reading his experience.

item.title: Rare Counting with Raku and Perl
item.description: We all know Arne is a Raku expert but his Perl skill is equally great. I love his Perl solutions with the flavour of Raku.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 102: Threads and Recursion
item.description: Enjoy the twists and turns described by Adam as he uses threads. Very interesting approach.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 102: Hash-counting String
item.description: I must admit Abigail made the task look so simple and easy to follow.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 102: Rare Numbers
item.description: You don't read Abigail's blog just for its technical value. I love the story he created around the task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 102
item.description: As always, Aaron goes into the finer details of the task and takes us on a memorable journey.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 102
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Rare Numbers" and "Hash-counting String" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 103
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Chinese Zodiac" and "What's playing?". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Gzip::Zopfli
item.description: Ben created a Perl version of Zopfli gzip compression.

item.title: Perl is dead ... when I'm dead!
item.description: Enkidu shared his thoughts about the state of Perl.

item.title: Monthly Report - February
item.description: My report on the previous month's activities, just to keep it going.

item.title: Perl Steering Council
item.description: A report from the 8th meeting of the Perl Steering Council.

item.title: Object::Pad v Moo v Moose v Core
item.description: A benchmark by Curtis reveals interesting data.

item.title: Bringing Modern OO To Perl
item.description: Curtis shows us the power of Corinna.

item.title: Learn automation using (R)?ex
item.description: During this Zoom session FErki, the maintainer of Rex, will teach Gabor how to get started with Rex to manage servers. It is today! You will also be able to ask your questions.

item.title: Rex vv1.13.3
item.description: Erki announced the latest release of Rex.

item.title: No :builder for the MVP
item.description: Big announcement by Curtis about the removal of :builder from Corinna.

item.title: Modern Perl Package Management | By ActiveState
item.description: While PPM is gone, the need to install dependencies without requiring a local build environment remains. ActivePerl allowed developers to get up and running quickly by delivering hundreds of popular modules with a single installation. Both use cases are now addressed in ActiveState’s new ecosystem.

item.title: #502 - Date with Corinna
item.description:
Hi there,

Are you a Perl fan? If yes then you are invited to meet Corinna, thanks to Curtis and his gang. I have been stalking Corinna ever since Curtis introduced Corinna, previously known as Cor. It is the best thing to have happened the recent times, in my humble opinion. I can't wait to see it becoming part of core Perl. But I know for a fact it is going to be a long wait. But I am sure the wait will be worthywhile. Before I forget, I would like to share another gist by Curtis where he compared the performance of core, Moose, Moo, and Object::Pad. We are also informed that the :builder is now officially removed from the Corinna MVP. Be prepared, it may come back, but for now, it's dead as documented here.

Is that the only good news about Perl?

Well, the short answer is No. As we all know, very soon we will have Perl 7 made public. I am little unsure about the launch date. One thing is for sure, Perl 7 is coming first and then Corinna. Please correct me if I am wrong. I am optimistic about Perl's future and confident that it is going to bounce back harder.

Please check out the rest of the newsletter for more fun news related to Perl family.
